reviewText:
This is one of those rare instances where I wish I had done as the negative reviews had suggested and not bought the game.

Sadly I thought that, because Retention was so cheap, it would be worth the risk of buying it.  That did not turn out to be true.  Now normally I enjoy games that go out of their way to be different and try something new.  While it is safe to say Retention is something different that does not make it good in any way.  A big problem with Retention is that it promises a story that never happens.  The game description says you're given the 'opportunity to tell a man by his memories', but I found that this just amounts to you picking one picture out of a group of three and then being given a small one sentence summary of the picture (as if you already couldn't tell just by looking at most of them).  The ending you recieve  after picking one picture out of all 85 groups of 3 doesn't help clarify the story in any way.  I've played through it multiple times now and I still can't decipher how or why I unlocked certain endings (and you can unlock multiple ones at once) and not others.

Confusion is honestly another reason why Retention is not a good game.  Again this is a game which in the description promises a 'user-friendly interface'.  I did not find that to be the case.  Right from the start the only helpful information given to you is how to move between slides and that you have to pick one picture out of a group of three.  The problem is that the game starts you at the very moment when the man presumably got into his biking accident.  You must then go back through all 85 of his memories (the pictures you'll get tired of looking at because they never change).  There are many problems with this.  First is the fact that it's very hard to tell what picture group you're on. It took me way too long to figure out that the only thing indicating what group you're on is a thin strip of white that appears below the square of film you're on.  Second is that if you somehow miss a picture group you're kind of screwed.  The only thing that separates picture groups you've selected a picture from, from ones you haven't is a tiny (very easy to miss) + sign.  Those two things coupled with being forced to flip through all the pictures you've already selected and seen to see if you've done enough to achieve an ending and in the end being denied one because you missed one group (out of 85) is downright frustrating.

In the end the only good thing I can say about Retention is that it has some pretty pictures and okay music.  There is also the fact it has cards, but even those can't make up for the fact that Retention is bad game.

reviewText:
I finished my first playthrough in about six minutes. With that experience, the only thing I can say with absolute certainty about this title is that I did not enjoy it.

The presentation is good and the game itself works fine, but it all seems a bit vague, to put it lightly. It's essentially a slideshow in which you decide on an injured man's memories. You are presented with a set of three photographs, from which you have to select one. This occurs numerous times, and makes up the entirety of the gameplay.

There are apparently a number of endings to unlock, but I honestly cannot find any motivation whatsoever to bring myself to work towards them. I understand that the story is to be partially constructed by the player. but I feel that more explicit explanations would have really helped to flesh out the narrative. Doing so may go against the game's vision, but not everyone (myself included) is able and/or willing to piece together a coherent narrative through a series of still images and some sparse accompanying text.

There is no denying that Retention is an original piece of work. As far as my experiences go, there is nothing else like it. However, that alone does not warrant a recommendation. This is a shame, as the method of delivery has so much promise.

reviewText:
The first 15 minutes were extremely confusing (especially seeing the ending)...but then I figured some things out about the gameplay...

There are 16 different endings, and 1 ending in which you have all 4 positive outcomes.  Trying to reach this ending requires either complete luck on what you pick (if you have no clue what criteria you're looking for and simply pick to the desirable qualities), or more likely, figuring out what each dimension requires.

This is a *very short* sociological game/puzzle that most people have no clue is actually a puzzle.  Puzzleception, lol.  Part of the amusement is how few people realize that there is indeed a game aspect to this, albeit short.

Since it does its job SO WELL of being mysterious, yet actually having intrinsic goals, I'm rating it 7/10.  However:
- It is very short (each game is max 10m30s, and usually less unless you're overthinking).  I figured out a 'best possible' ending permutation within about 33 minutes.
- You can't maximize or resize the window...this makes it painful to set up for a stream.
- There should be sound/music level options in the settings (it defaults to REALLY loud).
- Moving between slides should not be slowed down by the text animation...this makes it painful to scroll through the timeline in a normal way.  You have very limited time...I don't want to be stalled by the text animating one letter at a time.
- Perhaps better hints at the actual goal of the game would be a plus, but then again, I enjoyed being confused and then having the 'Aha!' Moment of figuring out what I needed to do.
- Replay value on this beyond finding the best possible and worst possible endings is near 0.

So, if there's no narrative, maybe the game is better read as modern poetry. Maybe the game needs to be read as discordant elements brought together in a way where the meaning needs to be pieced together. Okay, cool idea. I still think it could be better executed because, again, there are few repeated motifs throughout the piece and poems work almost entirely based off invoking a series of signs and signifiers that links the reader back to previous works and images in a canon of both literature and language. The game struggles to do this. And that's okay, in certain ways, but it makes it incredibly hard to analyze and piece things together.

Retention is an interesting experiment, that's for certain. I think it deserves to exist and should exist and needs to exist. Sadly, I just don't think this poem is any good.

reviewText:
Retention is as much of a game as those old picture slideshow disks from the early era of the CD-ROM. The “game” is practically nothing but a showcase of roughly 300 pictures compiled to 100 sets.
Each set randomly modifies the photos to contain one unaltered, one black & white, and one with distorted colours. What you choose from each set affects the outcome of the framing story, which is a short, but powerful allegory: a man falls with his bicycle and suffers temporary amnesia.

So… that’s it, really. Retention is nothing but a big photo album allegory about memories and how we value them. Not a game but an artistic expression that costs only one dollar to experience.

reviewText:
Ummm... It's a game, I guess?

I think the idea is that this game is supposed to be an experience, where you build the life of... someone, in the final moments of his life as his life flashes before his eyes.

Which, I mean, admittedly sounds interesting.

If there was more... gameplay and interaction. Or really a game at all. Like, from what I can tell, you pick one of several images based on how far along in his life he is after a timer starts, and you have to keep picking before a timer runs out. Forgive me if there isn't a timer, I don't exactly recall, been a while since I downloaded... this program.

Anyway, once you've gone through the whole life, it stops, and you can look back on what you put together.

That's it. All you do is pick pictures, and look back afterwards. I have no idea if what pictures you pick affect what's available next, but I don't think it does. It doesn't help that the pictures are generic as hell, and seem to just be stock images.

I don't know if this is supposed to pass as a game, or art, or... something, but it doesn't seem to be a game. You just pick pictures, and look them over afterwards. Nothing really interesting about them either, they're... just pictures. Sure, you could piece together the idea of a life where the main character does a lot of things, but... I mean, all you're really doing is just clicking pictures, and then it stops.

There's no replay value. At all. Heck, there isn't even anything to make one want to play it to begin with if they have any idea what they're getting into beyond the description. The description is much better than the game.

I don't recommend this. There's no fun to be had at all. I mean, maybe some people might get something out of this, but I don't see it.
